title: Ticket #6820: Improve Python bindings' JobEvent interface
description:
After more consultation, we've determined that the JobEvent API would be better (and more Pythonic) if the event-specific data were not represented as JobEvent object attributes, but by making JobEvent objects more dict()-like.

Specifically:

  • Add the __getitem__ function, remove the __getattr_ function, and implement cluster, proc, and timestamp.
  • Add __contains__(), keys(), values(), items(), and get().
  • Add __iter__(), iterkeys(), itervalues(), and iteritems().
  • Add __len__() and has_key().
  • Since JobEvent=s are immutable, do NOT implement =clear(), setdefault(), update(), pop(), popitem(), __missing__(), __setitem()__, or __delitem__().
  • Don't bother implementing __reverse__(), either.
  • Don't bother implementing copy(), either; it's a pain due to C++ pointer management in the underlying object, and seems like there's no reason to want an immutable object anyway.
  • Leave Python 3 issues for another ticket. (It may not be so bad; since a JobEvent is immutable, we don't need to worry about the 'live update' aspect of things, but can get away with just changing the mapping of keys(), values(), and items() to Py_{IterKeys,IterItems,IterValues}()
remarks:
[original description]

2018-Nov-11 20:43:00 by tlmiller:

After more consultation, we've determined that the JobEvent API would be better (and more Pythonic) if the event-specific data were not represented as JobEvent object attributes, but by making JobEvent objects more dict()-like. To avoid having to support the attribute API for 8.8, let's try to get rid of it before the 8.8.0 code-freeze.

To avoid losing access to event-specific data, add the __getitem__ function. To avoid losing access to non-event-specific data, make type, cluster, proc, and timestamp normal attributes. We would like to implement the rest of the dictionary interface as time permits, but a keys() method would address a specific probem; see #6814.

It seems like __contains__ would also be high on the list.

2018-Nov-11 21:06:57 by tlmiller:
When doing the documentation, be sure to mention which functions can throw what.

2018-Nov-13 12:38:00 by tlmiller:
Remaining from the 2.7 list:

  • has_key() is for backwards-compatibility only and thus seems kind of silly in a world with Python 3.7
  • The trio of iterkeys(), itervalues(), and iteritems() are only hard because it's unclear how to construct a Python iterator from C++ (I assume it's OK that we're returning Python lists of copies from keys(), values(), and items(); presumably there's a one-liner to convert such a thing to an iterator thereof.)
  • copy() and __len__() should be easy.
  • __iter__() just return __iterkeys__().

Since JobEvents are immutable, we are specifically not implementing clear(), setdefault(), update(), pop(), popitem(), __missing__(), __setitem()__, or __delitem__().

We're also not implementing __reverse__().

2018-Nov-13 12:42:46 by tlmiller:
Python 3.7 drops the iter*() methods, but changes keys(), values(), and items() to return 'view objects'. Not sure what the idiomatic solution here is, will worry about it later.

2018-Nov-13 14:54:34 by tlmiller:
There is a one-line to convert from lists to list iterators, although Boost didn't support it natively for some reason. Also, because the JobEvent is immutable, it's OK to return iterators over copies of the attributes/values/pairs, because they won't ever change. (This may only technically be a concern for Python 3, which we don't handle yet.)

2018-Nov-13 15:20:51 by tlmiller:
Actually, copy() is a bit of pain, because JobEvent can otherwise assume that it owns its pointers. We could make a deep copy or return the self object, but neither of those seem like a good idea, and it's not clear what use a copy of an immutable object would be anyway, so for now, let's skip it.

2018-Nov-14 10:58:36 by tlmiller:
Needs testing and docs.

2018-Nov-14 10:58:48 by tlmiller:
Rewriting history...

2018-Nov-16 11:32:35 by tlmiller:
Will add tests later.

2018-Nov-19 15:05:21 by johnkn:
CODE_REVIEW : changes look good.
